facts.text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 915 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 915 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal under Order V, rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Order V, rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules.

facts.text: V. S. Mani and Ganpat Rai for the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: V. S. Mani and Ganpat Rai, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1957 October 14 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. October 14. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-

facts.text: Petition under Art. 71 1 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 71 1  of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: On May 6 there was an election to the office of the President

anchor.surface_text: On May 6, there was an election to the office of the President

facts.text: Shri Rajendra Prasad was declared elected as President

anchor.surface_text: and Shri Rajendra Prasad was declared elected.

facts.text: Dr. N. B. Khare filed the present petition as an intending candidate

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Dr. N. B. Khare filed the present petition describing himself as an intending candidate

facts.text: Petitioner alleged violations of the provisions of the Constitution and election invalid

anchor.surface_text: and alleging that there had been violations of the provisions of the Constitution and that the election was in companysequence number valid.

facts.text: Prayers to enquire into doubts regarding Presidential election and quash proceedings as void

anchor.surface_text: The prayers in the petition are that grave doubts that exist in companynection with the Presidential election be enquired into, resolved and decided and the entire proceedings of the Presidential election be quashed as void .

facts.text: Registrar of this Court returned the petition

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of this Court returned the petition as number being in companyformity with the provisions of the Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952  XXXI of 1952 ,

facts.text: Petition not in conformity with Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections Act, 1952 (XXXI of 1952)

anchor.surface_text: and as number satisfying the requirements of the Rules of this Court companytained in 0. XXXVII-A

facts.text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 requires election petition presented by candidate or ten or more electors

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 provides that numberelection shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to the Supreme Court in accordance with the provisions of the Act and of the Rules made by the Supreme Court under Art. 145 of the Constitution and it further provides that it should be presented by any candidate at such election or by ten or more electors.

facts.text: Rules in O. XXXVII-A framed by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The Rules framed by this Court with reference to this matter are companytained in 0. XXXVII-A.

facts.text: Rule 3 of O. XXXVII-A requires court-fee of Rs. 250

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 prescribes that a companyrt-fee of the value of Rs. 250 should be paid on the petition

facts.text: Rule 12 requires deposit of Rs. 2,000 as security for costs

anchor.surface_text: and r. 12 requires the petitioner to deposit a sum of Rs. 2,000 in cash as security for the payment of companyts that may become payable by him.

facts.text: Petitioner not entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act

facts.text: Petition defective as did not comply with requirements of rr. 3 and 12

anchor.surface_text: and his petition was also defective as it did number companyply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

facts.text: Petition returned by the Registrar

anchor.surface_text: It was accordingly returned by the Registrar.

facts.text: Present appeal brought against the Registrar's order

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, the present appeal has been brought.

facts.text: Mr. Mani contended that petition is outside purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and O. XXXVII-A

anchor.surface_text: It is firstly companytended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules.

facts.text: Act XXXI of 1952 passed by Parliament under Art. 71 3

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.
Appeal under Order V, rule 3 of the Supreme Court Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It is firstly companytended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules. It is argued that the Supreme Court is invested with jurisdiction to enquire into and decide all doubts and disputes arising out of or in companynection with the election of the President,

issues.text: Whether the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of O. XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules because it is founded upon doubts as to the validity of the election rather than a dispute as to the election

anchor.surface_text: It is firstly contended by Mr. Mani that the present petition is outside the purview of Act XXXI of 1952 and of XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules. It is argued that the Supreme Court is invested with jurisdiction to enquire into and decide all doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of the President,

issues.text: Whether Act XXXI of 1952 and O. XXXVII-A are void as derogating from the jurisdiction conferred on the Supreme Court by Article 71(1) to enquire into and decide all disputes and doubts arising out of or in connection with the election of the President, particularly given the restrictions in section 18

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the Act and the Rules in question are void on the ground that they derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court to enquire into and decide all disputes and doubts arising out of or in connection with the election of the President or the Vice-President. It is argued that under s. 18, the election could be set aside only on certain grounds and that further under clause (b) it could be done only if the result of the election is shown to have been materially affected,

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach the Supreme Court under Article 71(1) whenever an election has been held in breach of constitutional provisions, independent of the statute

anchor.surface_text: And finally it is contended that the petitioner has a right as a citizen to approach this Court under Art. 71(1) whenever an election has been held in breach of the constitutional provisions.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner is entitled to present the election petition under section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 as he is neither a candidate at the election nor ten or more electors

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 provides that no election shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to the Supreme Court in accordance with the provisions of the Act and of the Rules made by the Supreme Court under Art. 145 of the Constitution and it further provides that it should be presented by any candidate at such election or by ten or more electors.

issues.text: Whether the petition complies with the requirements of Rules 3 and 12 of Order XXXVII-A of the Supreme Court Rules regarding court fee and security deposit

anchor.surface_text: The Rules framed by this Court with reference to this matter are contained in O. XXXVII-A. Rule 3 prescribes that a court-fee of the value of Rs. 250 should be paid on the petition and r. 12 requires the petitioner to deposit a sum of Rs. 2,000 in cash as security for the payment of costs that may become payable by him.

arguments.claim: Petitioner is not a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act as neither candidate nor ten or more electors

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of Act XXXI of 1952 provides that numberelection shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to the Supreme Court in accordance with the provisions of the Act and of the Rules made by the Supreme Court under Art. 145 of the Constitution and it further provides that it should be presented by any candidate at such election or by ten or more electors. The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act

arguments.claim: Petition defective as did not comply with requirements of rr. 3 and 12 of O. XXXVII-A

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 prescribes that a companyrt-fee of the value of Rs. 250 should be paid on the petition and r. 12 requires the petitioner to deposit a sum of Rs. 2,000 in cash as security for the payment of companyts that may become payable by him. The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act and his petition was also defective as it did number companyply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12.

arguments.claim: Article 71(1) merely prescribes the forum; does not prescribe conditions for petition to set aside election

anchor.surface_text: Article 71 1  merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in companynection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does number prescribe the companyditions under which the petition for setting aside an election companyld be presented.

arguments.claim: Under Art. 71(3), Parliament authorised to make law regulating election matters; Act XXXI of 1952 validly passed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

arguments.claim: Right to move for setting aside election not common law right; must be conferred by statute and enforced per its conditions

anchor.surface_text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are number companymon law rights. They must be companyferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the companyditions laid down therein.

arguments.claim: Petitioner has no right to move for setting aside election except per Act XXXI of 1952

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is number a person entitled to apply under s. 14 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s. 14 requires election petition to be presented by any candidate at such election or by ten or more electors

holdings.text: his petition was also defective as it did not comply with the requirements of rr. 3 and 12

holdings.text: In substance the petition is one calling the election in question and it must satisfy the requirements of Act XXXI of 1952 and of the Rules in O. XXXVII-A

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. When once an election has been held, any doubt concerning its validity is material only as a ground for setting aside the election and that in fact is the prayer in the petition itself In substance the petition is one calling the election in question and it must satisfy the requirements of Act XXXI of 1952 and of the Rules in 0. XXXVII-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Any doubt concerning validity of election held is ground for setting aside; prayer seeks to quash election proceedings

holdings.text: Article 71(1) merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in connection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does not prescribe the conditions under which the petition for setting aside an election could be presented

anchor.surface_text: Article 71 1  merely prescribes the forum in which disputes in companynection with the election of the President and Vice-President would be enquired into. It does number prescribe the companyditions under which the petition for setting aside an election companyld be presented.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 71(1) invests jurisdiction in Supreme Court as forum but silent on conditions for petitions

holdings.text: Under Art. 71(3), it is Parliament that is authorised to make law for regulating any matter relating to or connected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 71 3 , it is Parliament that is authorised It  make law for regulating any matter relating to or companynected with the election of the President or Vice President, and Act XXXI of 1952 has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 71(3) expressly empowers Parliament to legislate on election matters including conditions

holdings.text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are not common law rights. They must be conferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the conditions laid down therein

anchor.surface_text: The right to stand for election and the right to move for setting aside an election are number companymon law rights. They must be companyferred by statute and can be enforced only in accordance with the companyditions laid down therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election challenge rights unknown to common law; exist only if and as provided by statute

holdings.text: The petitioner has, therefore, no right to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has, therefore, numberright to move for setting aside the election except in accordance with the provisions of Act XXXI of 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's standing and procedure governed strictly by Act XXXI of 1952 under Art. 71(3)

holdings.text: The contention that the Act and the Rules derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Art. 71(1) must accordingly be rejected

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the Act and the Rules derogate from the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Art. 71 1  must accordingly be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act and Rules authorised by Art. 71(3); compatible with Art. 71(1) forum prescription
